question: Question_01_(b)
statement:
\textbf{Sequences and Series: Short Answer Problems - Determine whether
the following sequences and series converge (full marks for correct
answer with justification; work must be shown for partial marks)}

Does the sequence
$\left(\frac{n^3 + 2}{\sqrt{n^6+3} + \sqrt[3]{27n^9 + 1}} \right)_{n \geq 1}$
converge? If it does, calculate the limit.
sols:
Proceeding as in the hint, we have

\begin{align*}
\frac{n^3 + 2}{\sqrt{n^6+3} + \sqrt[3]{27n^9 + 1}} &= \frac{n^3(1 + \tfrac{2}{n^3})}{\sqrt{n^6(1+\tfrac{3}{n^6})} + \sqrt[3]{27n^9(1 + \tfrac{1}{27n^9})}} \\
&= \frac{n^3(1 + \tfrac{2}{n^3})} {n^3\sqrt{(1+\tfrac{3}{n^6})} + 3n^3\sqrt[3]{(1 + \tfrac{1}{27n^9})}} \\
&= \frac{1 + \tfrac{2}{n^3}} {\sqrt{(1+\tfrac{3}{n^6})} + 3\sqrt[3]{(1 + \tfrac{1}{27n^9})}}\end{align*}

Taking the limit as \emph{n} tends to infinity in the last equality
above yields

$\lim_{n \to \infty} \frac{n^3 + 2}{\sqrt{n^6+3} + \sqrt[3]{27n^9 + 1}} = \lim_{n \to \infty}\frac{1 + \tfrac{2}{n^3}} {\sqrt{(1+\tfrac{3}{n^6})} + 3\sqrt[3]{(1 + \tfrac{1}{27n^9})}} = \frac{1}{1 + 3} = \frac{1}{4}$

and so the sequence converges to one fourth.
hints:
Don't let the square and cube roots fool you! This is still essentially
a polynomial divided by a polynomial so factor out the largest power of
\emph{n} in both the numerator and the denominator.
What are the dominant terms when $n$ is large?
